channel.title: Stories from bloomberg.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best bloomberg.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: The Crash Of The $8.5 Billion Global Flower Trade
item.description: As people everywhere cancel events and big cut-flower orders, the ripples reach into Dutch auction halls and Kenyan rose fields.

item.title: Oil Prices Just Crashed To Less Than $1/Barrel. Here's What It's Like To Actually Try To Buy A Barrel
item.description: Oil prices crashed to new lows on Monday amid the pandemic. Here's what happened when Bloomberg's Tracy Alloway tried to buy a barrel back in 2015.

item.title: Seoul's Full Cafes, Apple Store Lines Show Mass Testing Success
item.description: Cafes bustled with customers, parks teemed with sunbathers, and the first Apple store to reopen outside China had lines snaking out the door as many South Koreans — almost all wearing masks — emerged from months of self-isolation.

item.title: Carnival Executives Knew They Had A Virus Problem. They Kept The Party Going Anyway
item.description: At least 1,500 people on the company's cruise ships have been diagnosed with COVID-19, dozens have died, and the lawsuits are just getting started.

item.title: Trump Says He'll Unveil Reopening Plans With Virus Hitting Peak
item.description: President Donald Trump said he will unveil guidelines to relax stay-at-home rules on Thursday, citing signs that the coronavirus outbreak is plateauing in parts of the country.

item.title: Coronavirus Survivors Hope For Immunity — The Reality Is More Complicated
item.description: Scientists are working hard to understand the extent to which antibodies provide protection against COVID-19.

item.title: The US Postal Service Has Never Been More Important, Or More Endangered
item.description: The agency was already facing tumbling mail volume, financial losses, and hostility from Washington. And then coronavirus hit.

item.title: The Mystery Of The Millionaire Hermit (2019)
item.description: He spent years scrimping and saving. But without a will, where's his money going?

item.title: Zoom Is Suddenly Critical Infrastructure. No One Is More Surprised Than Zoom
item.description: Eric Yuan built a tech unicorn in the unflashy business of enterprise communications. Then, suddenly, the world needed it to be something else.

item.title: Trader Joe's Employees Say Virus Response Was Haphazard And Chaotic
item.description: Interviews with dozens of crew members paint a picture of a tumultuous two weeks as the company's policies rapidly changed.

item.title: China's Post-Quarantine Divorce Spike Is A Warning To The Rest Of The Locked-Down World
item.description: Filings started rising in March as couples emerged from quarantine.

item.title: DJI Won The Drone Wars, And Now It's Paying The Price
item.description: China's flashiest global brand has a 77% share of America's consumer drone sales. It also has to deal with coronavirus, the trade war, a $150 million fraud scandal, and skeptics in the US and Chinese governments.

item.title: Hospitals Tell Doctors They'll Be Fired If They Speak Out About Lack Of Gear
item.description: Hospitals are threatening to fire health-care workers who publicize their working conditions during the coronavirus pandemic — and have in some cases followed through.

item.title: China To Lift Lockdown Over Virus Epicenter Wuhan On April 8
item.description: China's Hubei province said it will allow transportation to resume for the city of Wuhan on April 8, effectively lifting a mass quarantine over the city where the coronavirus first emerged last December.

item.title: Amazon Drivers Received Single Wipe To Clean Vans Before Shifts
item.description: In interviews, some contract drivers worry their safety is taking a back seat to the swift delivery of products.

item.title: A Famed AIDS Researcher Is Racing To Find A Coronavirus Treatment
item.description: Columbia's David Ho is leading a group that's trying to compress a five-year process into one.

item.title: Ten-Minute Coronavirus Test for $1 Could Be Game Changer
item.description: Already exhausted from testing for monkeypox and Lassa fever, Nigerian molecular bio-engineer Nnaemeka Ndodo had to work well past midnight earlier this month to find out if six Chinese construction workers were infected with the coronavirus.

item.title: How Seattle's Patient Zero Spread Coronavirus Despite Ebola-Style Lockdown
item.description: The man who would become Patient Zero for the new coronavirus outbreak in the US appeared to do everything right.

item.title: Tea Boy To Tattooed Trader: A Secret Tipster's Life And Death
item.description: James Harris was plugged into a network that included insider traders and operated on two continents.

item.title: The Coronavirus Hunter Is Racing For Answers In A Locked-Down Lab
item.description: A University of North Carolina scientist who has been chasing viruses for decades may hold the key to a cure.

item.title: Farmers Fight John Deere Over Who Gets To Fix An $800,000 Tractor
item.description: The right-to-repair movement has come to the heartland, where some farmers are demanding access to the software that runs their equipment.

item.title: Can We Get A Vaccine Early? How The Rich Are Preparing For Coronavirus
item.description: One investor may fly to Idaho with or without family. A doctor in a Colorado ski town is soothing wealthy clients who want a cure. And one New Yorker called up the hospital with his name on it.

item.title: Printing's Not Dead: The $35 Billion Fight Over Ink Cartridges
item.description: America's onetime innovation icons are wrestling over their biggest remaining piles of money.

item.title: The Bizarre Rich-People Secrets I Learned Undercover At Canyon Ranch Spa
item.description: "We have one regular that — no matter what he orders — wants his [already hot] entree zapped in the microwave for exactly eight and a half minutes."

item.title: The $35 Billion Fight Over Ink Cartridges
item.description: America's onetime innovation icons are wrestling over their biggest remaining piles of money.

item.title: Reddit's Profane, Greedy Traders Are Shaking Up The Stock Market
item.description: A band of Reddit users is hijacking stocks and defying even the coronavirus sell-off.
item.kicker: A PENNY STOCK FOR YOUR THOUGHTS

item.title: In America's Richest Town, $500k A Year Is Now Below Average
item.description: You could easily drive through this leafy Silicon Valley suburb without realizing you were in America's richest neighborhood.

item.title: SoftBank's $375 Million Bet On Pizza Went Really Bad Really Fast
item.description: Inside the mass firings at Zume, one of Masayoshi Son's latest investment debacles.

item.title: The Death Of A Doctor Poses The Greatest Threat To China's Xi Yet
item.description: Citizens begin to question not just the government response to coronavirus, but the overall competence of the Communist Party.

item.title: The Hot New Endurance Trend Is 'Everesting' — Climbing 29,000 Feet In 36 Hours
item.description: The challenge: Hike to the summit of Vermont's Stratton Mountain. Catch the gondola down. Repeat 16 times. That adds up to a little more than 29,029 feet of elevation — the equivalent of Mount Everest, without the altitude sickness and oxygen tanks.

item.title: How To Be In The Richest 1% Around The World
item.description: From Brazil to India, a breakdown of the richest of the rich.

item.title: Family Builds $3.8 Billion Fortune, One Pint Of Blood At A Time
item.description: Spain's Grifols family has prospered with storefront collection centers across US.

item.title: Fires In Australia And The Amazon Released Billions Of Tons Of CO2 In 2019
item.description: Last year's mammoth wildfires in the Amazon, Indonesia and the Arctic Circle triggered a global conversation about the environmental and economic consequences of climate change.

item.title: I Used Dark Web Ransomware To Sabotage My Boss
item.description: Encrypting data to extort payment is as easy as purchasing software — almost anyone can do it.

item.title: China Sacrifices A Province To Save The World From Coronavirus
item.description: "It's like fighting a war — some things are hard, but must be done."

item.title: A Small-Rocket Maker Is Running A Different Kind Of Space Race
item.description: Astra, Darpa's rocket startup of choice, is preparing to launch satellites into orbit in record time.

item.title: There's Another Virus Stalking America: It's Called The Flu
item.description: While the world scrambles to contain the coronavirus, the U.S. flu season may be taking a turn for the worse. It's already killed 10,000.

item.title: This Could Be America's Most Expensive Home Ever — If It Can Find A Buyer
item.description: Seven years in the making, a $500 million California mansion will test ultra-luxury appetite

item.title: Behind The Race To Contain China's Killer Bug
item.description: "What we are facing now is an extreme, severe and abrupt public health crisis."

item.title: Meet The Tesla Skeptics Who Shorted Elon Musk
item.description: TSLAQ is an informal collection of obsessives pushing back against the cult of Elon.

item.title: The Failure Of The Fast-Fashion Forever 21 Empire
item.description: If the fast-fashion giant is going to survive bankruptcy, its idiosyncratic owners might have to give up control.

item.title: For Bumble, The Future Isn't Female, It's Female Marketing
item.description: '"We're not here to capitalize on equality,' Wolfe Herd said about Bumble's marketing. 'We don't need to slap 'The Future is Female' on a T-shirt and put it on our store.' It had, however, posted the phrase to Instagram."
item.kicker: CAN A DATING APP CHANGE THE WORLD?

item.title: The Tokyo Job
item.description: How an elite extraction team spirited Carlos Ghosn out of Japan by studying hotel layouts and airport security.

item.title: The Hidden Dangers Of The Great Index Fund Takeover
item.description: The Big Three — BlackRock, Vanguard, and State Street — are the most important players in corporate America. Whether they like it or not.
item.kicker: THIS LITTLE PIGGY SWALLOWED THE MARKET

item.title: Venezuela's Latest Problem Is There Are Now Too Many Dollars
item.description: Businesses and consumers stash away semi-illicit greenbacks.

item.title: The Hacker Who Took Down A Country
item.description: Daniel Kaye, also known as Spdrman, found regular jobs tough but corporate espionage easy. He's about to get out of prison.

item.title: Chill, It Might Not Be That Bad: The Optimist's Guide To 2020
item.description: Instead of looking at what could go wrong, we're asking you to look at what could go right.

item.title: The Volatile Economics Of Natural Vanilla In Madagascar
item.description: Watching booms and busts in Madagascar, the world's primary source of natural vanilla.

item.title: A Third Of America's Economy Is Concentrated In 1% Of Its Counties
item.description: The US economy is increasingly concentrated in large cities and near the coasts and less so in rural areas.

item.title: Ex-Renault-Nissan Chair Carlos Ghosn Faces The Trial Of His Life
item.description: The auto industry icon will be fighting to stay out of prison—and to salvage his legacy.
